title: 105_hr2792
content: The Act is titled the "Employment Discrimination Award Tax Relief Act" and allows for the deduction of expenses related to asserting or prosecuting claims of employment discrimination based on age, gender, race, or other prohibited forms. The Act allows for deductions of expenses for employees bringing or prosecuting employment discrimination claims based on age, gender, race, or other prohibited forms. The amendment applies to expenses for employees bringing employment discrimination claims based on age, gender, race, or other prohibited forms, effective for taxable years beginning after December 31, 1985. For tax purposes, expenses related to asserting or prosecuting claims for prohibited employment discrimination are treated differently under the alternative minimum tax rules. Expenses for asserting or prosecuting claims of employment discrimination are treated differently under alternative minimum tax rules. The amendment made by this section applies to expenses for asserting or prosecuting claims of employment discrimination in taxable years beginning after December 31, 1985. Exclusion from gross income for damages received on account of age, gender, race, and other forms of prohibited employment discrimination. Amendment to the Internal Revenue Code allows exclusion of amounts received for employment discrimination claims from gross income. Effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 1985. Amendment to the Internal Revenue Code allows exclusion of income from backpay received on account of age, gender, race, and other forms of prohibited employment discrimination. Amendment to the Internal Revenue Code allows exclusion of income from backpay received on account of age, gender, race, and other forms of prohibited employment discrimination. The Internal Revenue Code limits the tax imposed on employment discrimination backpay received by a taxpayer in a taxable year. It ensures that the tax does not exceed the amount if the backpay was not included in gross income and no deduction was allowed for expenses related to the discrimination claim. The tax on employment discrimination backpay is limited by the Internal Revenue Code to prevent it from exceeding the amount if the backpay was not included in gross income. Definitions for backpay and employment discrimination backpay are provided in the code. The tax on employment discrimination backpay is limited by the Internal Revenue Code to prevent it from exceeding the amount if the backpay was not included in gross income. The backpay period refers to the period during which the services are performed to which the employment discrimination backpay is attributable. The backpay period for employment discrimination is defined as the next highest number of whole taxable years. The average annual net backpay amount is calculated by dividing the excess of non-taxable income over non-deductible amounts by the number of years in the backpay period. A clerical amendment is made to the Internal Revenue Code. The amendments made by this section apply to backpay awards received on account of employment discrimination starting after December 31, 1985. Refund or credit of overpayment resulting from these amendments can be allowed within 1 year of the enactment of this Act, even if prevented by any law or rule of law.
